author: philbarnes
content: If you get too into the weeds with a shit-ton of plugins, don't be afraid to start it over with just a single EQ and compressor. I surprise myself with how often a break and reset gets me to a better vocal mix in a fraction of the moves.

author: BatMeckley
content:
This is easily the nicest and most knowledgeable forum for audio discussion I’ve ever seen. I’m taken aback daily on Gearspace and theGearPage how people with absolutely no real world experience wax poetic about the quality of this piece of gear over that piece, and how quickly every thread devolves into nothing useful. On this discord experts and beginners alike are constantly giving and receiving real knowledge that actually helps make records, rather than “which plugin gives the LUFS”. I’ve been at this music thing a long time and nearly every single day I learn something new and useful to apply to my next session. 

If someone really came onto this forum and found the heat of this particular kitchen too hot for them, I imagine life might continue to be hard for them. This is about as good as it gets, and if there’s a place giving out better info from better people I’d love to hear about it. What @oaklandmatt has curated is pretty special. It’s not a daycare, it’s a place to get better.

author: Slow Hand

Came here to say this.

My personal pet peeve are plugins that still use a GUI that functions like a mixing channel strip. (SSL, Metric Halo, UAD, etc).

I think a big reason I never got into SSL-style EQs is because the experience of using one with a mouse sucks so much. I hate having to boost a freq, move my mouse to the freq sweep, move my mouse to the Q, move it back to the freq, etc. 

Just give me a graphic interface like Pro-Q3. It is *the* superior choice when working on a computer.

author: Calvin Lauber
content: Any of you all ever used the Gaffel Synced Band Splitter? I was treated to a bit of a real life MWTM with Chris Coady last night (super kind guy) and he was showing me this plugin to mix a big pop vocal sound. He duplicated the lead vocal twice to have three tracks and had this plugin as the first insert on each track, split into three bands for each channel, low vocal, mid vocal, high end vocal. The plugin auto syncs the band settings in all instances whenever you adjust a band. He was saying Serban uses this plugin and does that exact thing on some songs. After treating each track with some eq/comp/saturation the vocal sounded really big but balanced. And it’s like $60 so I think I’m going to have to grab it. Probably could do this with other plugins but I appreciated the auto-syncing function and also didn’t notice any weird phase issues which you could maybe run into trying to create the bands by hand?

author: Rollmottle
content:
i think this is where the Youtube/Tiktok discourse has largely done a disservice to people who think "pro results" are just a plugin away. in all but the most anomalous cases, collaborators are an integral part of creative enterprise, especially one that wishes to engage the commercial marketplace. that's not really the message you hear out there and i can understand why people would balk at any number when they approach somebody to bring in to their project.

it seems like part of this is re-setting expectations on what it costs to hire professionals to help bring your art to the world and helping people understand what different roles can bring. part of it is probably a misunderstanding that this doesn't necessarily have to cost a fortune, but it may cost just a little more than somebody has now and all they need to do is save a little more and come back. 

it’s a complex topic with no easy answers. and of course, at the core of it is making sure we are delivering value at any point where we are involved.

author: Adam Thein
content:
Something that resonated with what @BatMeckley said an hour ago - “don’t be afraid to start from zero again”

Especially while you are learning maybe trying a few approaches is worth the extra time when there is not a deadline you are up against.

I’ve had a few mixes this year where I’m toward the end of the mix and have been living with a vocal chain for a while and just pull everything off it only to realize it just needed a little more top end and a touch of automation here and there when I had 8 plugins on it before.  That’s maybe an exaggeration but the idea is lean into what’s great about digital mixing - save a version, try something new.  If you are versioning there is always a way back to where you were.  Repetition and experimentation will help you find ways to solve problems and speed things up for you down the road.

author: Rollmottle
content:
1. Take everything but your mixer out of your summing signal path. Set its gain to where it will be when you're summing.
2. Insert a tone generator in your DAW and route it out to your summing rig.
3. Insert a trim plugin that can adjust L&R separately on the summing return in your DAW. Insert a meter like Izotope Insight before it if your trim plugin doesn't have good metering.
4. Play a 1khz sine wave from your tone generator.
5. See what your return is showing you.
6. Offset the level accordingly. 
7. Profit.

author: Slow Hand
content:
The sleeper modulation plugin for me is the (free!) *Valhalla SuperMassive*. It's meant for huge, expansive delays and verbs, but if you turn down the delay time to the < 50ms range, and turn up the feedback it gives an effect that's somewhere between a chorus and room sound. Blend to taste.

And don't forget to try the different algorithms. They make a big difference.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Nowadays I am committing tracks sooner and sooner in the process. It's partly a result of me feeling more assured in my choices, and partly me aiming to reduce the complexity of my sessions as I proceed through them. I hate large sessions.

Nothing is more demoralizing than that feeling of being in the final mix and still auditioning new kick drum samples at the final hour. I had a production/mix like that last year and it drove me crazy because nothing felt locked in. I had no fixed point in the mix to work from or to build off of.

Nowadays whenever I think to myself "This _ feels great and like a finished record" I will immediately commit it to audio to prevent myself from unraveling the work I've already done.

I'm the type of person that if I saw a channel with twelve plugins on it I get suspicious and start paring it back to see if I can create the sound with less processing. Sometimes this is the right move, but if I start tweaking the compressor in the 2nd plugin slot that's downstream of 8 more plugins that's a good way to de-stabilize the entire sound you've built up. Committing sooner prevents me from unraveling too much of the audio.

author: cian riordan
content: I've definitely been reconing with this more and more. I thought I established my mixer 'brand' as someone who builds things from the ground up, a fresh start on the song. Clearly there's been an evolution to things coming in more fully baked, but recently I had a whole record where the sessions came in fully baked. They sounded very good, were incredibly intricate in how they were layered, and the bus processing was such a massive part of the sound that anytime I tried to build up something my own way, it wasn't even in the same ballpark. I ended up buying every plugin on the clients master bus and 'resigned' myself to small tweaks. I totally changed my approach and it became incredibly liberating... to know that something is already so close to being finished, but spending my time throughtfully making small changes that amounted to a 10-15% gain.

author: Slow Hand
content: Since you're trying to get more juice out of Pro-L2, I would give this guide a quick read. author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Man it goes both ways- sometimes if you’ve got problem frequencies or too much bottom a compressor will react to the wrong things, and depending on what you’re using to compress there may be problem frequencies imparted. I wouldn’t be afraid to eq both before and after compression/saturation. 

There’s no limit on the amount of plugins you can put on a vocal chain, so often I approach it with a lot of things doing a little bit at a time, just adding or subtracting things I’m looking for.

But if more freedoms is stressing you out, try this approach. 
Add a comp in the second slot
See what jumps out at you, and then decide if you need to eq what’s going into the comp, or just what’s coming out of it.
Subtractive eq 
De essing 
More compression/saturation
More subtractive eq/de essing 
Additive eq 
Any final touches (limiting, saturation, de essing, etc)
Fx 

Use as many plugs as you think you need to. 

Then go back and disable everything, adding them back one at a time to make sure everything you’ve done is helpful on a fresh listen. 

If you love everything you’ve done but need a little more on the chain, commit and start as if that’s your recorded vocal and go from there.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yeah. Soft synth patches are often programmed to take up a massive amount of space and sound as impressive as possible. It's a pet-peeve of mine when presets are dripping in verb and echo. I wish more synths had a master-echo bypass option across all patches.

I also immediately turn off any stereo-widening or spatial effects, and/or reduce it to mono by dropping a channel or narrowing it with a utility plugin.

Funnily it took me a while to internalize the lesson that most mix elements sound best closer to mono.

author: peterlabberton
content:
I think Auto-Align 2 just totally saved my ass with an acoustic gtr/vocal recording/mix.

Was doing a little one-off tracking date with a big artist I'm trying to work with more and more, and I feel like I didn't do my best on the recording side. Could have and should have taken up a member here on a generous mic lending offer (you know who you are 🙏 ), but decided I could roll with my own gear. Acoustic gtr and vocal, tracked together—would have done the two figure 8 mics/use the nulls move with the borrowed mics, but I don't have two fig 8 mics right now. A drive across town would have gotten me the right tools for the job and made everything smooth and easy. Lesson learned: get the right shit no matter what!

Artist left in good spirits, job done, fine. But I was super bummed, I had wanted to blow them away. Had to step away for a few days, and then spent most of yesterday trying every trick in my book to get the phase of the vocal and gtr mic to be happy (it sounded fine so long as the artist wasn't singing loud—then it became phase city in a few loud passages as the gtr mic got more and more vocal). Time adjuster, playing with Little Labs IBP, EQ, whatever. Still mostly a huge bummer. But! Auto-Align 2 did some spectral phase shift magic that I don't think I would have been able to suss out on my own—holy shit, what a relief! Maybe I love our new AI overlords after all. (I think this plug-in claims AI magic... whatev, it's tight.)

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'm really enjoying the new *VCME Soft Clip* from Goodhertz, which comes free with their *VCME* limiter. They spun the clipping section off into it's own plugin and it feels great to overdrive it. Everything breaks up in a musical way, and the slew controls are good for voicing how the dynamics drive the distortion at the attack or tail of the sound.

Maybe the distortion algorithms aren't anything new, but they sound amazing and the entire tool is designed in a way that's musical, which I think is one Goodhertz's biggest strengths. They have a great intuition for voicing parameters and their curves in a way that is highly musical and hard to go wrong with. They feel like toys that bring joy and not like I have to crunch the physics in my mind to get results. https://goodhertz.com/vcme-soft-clip/

author: Zack Hames
content:
The technical skills are all more or less the same, but you’ll be doing different tasks. Editing VO quickly, using Frames for your grid / worrying about timecode, importing AAF or OMF files from video editors via Import Session Data in PT. It’s more about understanding the expectations and workflow for Post Production that has a learning curve compared to album production.

Oh, and understanding ISDN and Source Connect to connect with other studios, hating when people send you VO files that are in 44.1 and poorly processed when you specifically asked for raw/48k/24 bit, video people thinking they can do audio, replacing shitty sfx they rip from YouTube with decent ones, and being a wizard with Izotope RX suite to remove every little noise, crackle, train, plane, fountain, waterfall, wind, you name it, are some of the things you’ll spend your time doing that maybe you wouldn’t if you were producing music. It keeps me very fresh in pro tools which is nice and I’ve learned a lot about working insanely fast and communicating with clients as well as instilling confidence. It’s a really interesting field and the $$$ is great.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Using a delay plugin for your pre-delays is nice for a couple of reasons:
A) Tempo-synced pre-delay values
B) You can do things like ping-pong or spread the imaging of your pre-delays for additional effect
C) If the delay has tone-shaping features with different personalities (like on Echo Boy Jr.) you can quickly apply different sonic character to the signal going into your reverb.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I do a version of this a lot when mixing. If I feel like a key element has gotten way too many layers of paint I duplicate the channel, strip off the plugins, try again and then A/B against my original to verify that I've not lost anything vital. 

Usually I'm able to recreate the vibe I need with fewer steps once I can see what's working and it has far better definition because there's less crufty processing happening.

author: JakeTB
content:
All of @popaganda. 's info is great here. To go one step further on the controls for a beginner- If you are using eq, that implies that you have already diagnosed a problem, which you'll be solving with eq. When you think of that problem, what words do you use? (i.e., this is way too dark, this needs a little more highs, that frequency hurts, etc.). 
If you find yourself talking about broader things like "highs" or "lows", that probably indicates a wide Q is appropriate. If you find yourself talking about "that ringing" or "the fundamental", that probably indicates a narrow Q is appropriate. 

Frequency, Bandwidth (Q), and Gain are all balance elements, as eq is a tool for balancing frequencies with one another. I'd avoid using the key of the song or phase when considering eq choices as a beginner. Just train and trust your ears.

A tool that can be helpful in training your ears for EQ usage is "Blindfold EQ" by Audiothing (https://www.audiothing.net/effects/blindfold-eq/), which is a free EQ plugin with no numbers or indicators for the controls.

I've been having luck recently with using a multisampled drum kit like any of the Addictive Drums, Kontakt kits, SD3, etc, then sending a trigger, finding a similarly tuned drum they have sampled and mute the close mics - you are left with just the recorded ambience which can be convincing enough to add some air without sounding as unnatural as verb.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
A+ advice above. Few small things I'd add:

1. Don't be overly concerned by what you see on the screen. A certain style on a compressor that says "clean" may not actually be. It may have more harmonics than various other styles on the same plugin. Certain meters move faster than others, not all 10ms attack times will actually attack the same, certain GUIs that imply some sort of analog modeling may not actually do so, etc. Just listen and trust your ears.

2. If you can't hear certain aspects right away, that's fine too. You can't force it, don't rush it. Still just listen and trust your ears.

3. I liked compression less when my monitoring was lousy and not suitably dynamic, because everything sounded more compressed than it actually was.

author: Slow Hand
content:
One habit that I've picked up using Ableton that's really handy is doing all of my volume rides and mute automation with a *utility* plugin. This gives me a few advantages:

1. I can place the rides/mutes exactly where I want in the signal path (into a compressor, before a verb, after a verb, etc)

2. I can easily enable/disable the automation if I want to A/B or simplify while solving another problem.

3. My faders are left solely for global level changes and I can easily mute the channel without mute automation turning it back on/off.

author: JustinLeu
content:
A few more thoughts/ideas that I really like to do.

If using verb as an insert on an instrument:
- on insert 1–put Mondomod (or any panning plugin that will change the track from mono to stereo)  then use this as the pan before the reverb. This lets you place the instrument in the stereo field of the reverb. Doing it with mondo mod allows you to keep it static but also automate movement (small or large) within the verb 🙂

Another idea:
Use Waves StudioVerse (or similar plugin that allows this routing)
-parallel split the dry/wet 
-wet gets what ever verb you want
-Leave the wet panned out-wide
-pan the dry in towards the middle 

Doing it with StudioVerse allows you to avoid making aux-sends and keep it all on the track level. (Very useful on bgvs)

Last idea:
Use a pan control plugin (S1, TrackControl, etc) after the verb so you can make it more mono if you want. 

I love verb/dly haha thanks for letting me talk  about it here…my wife is tired of hearing about it 🥲

author: sethearnest
content:
The Way to Export All Tracks from Logic to Equal the Exact Mix that the Artist/Producer Left Off From™

1. Any busses you want printed need to be showing as "tracks" in the Arrange window. You can do this from your Mix Window by selecting all busses/auxes you want to print, right-click, choose "Create Track", and now those Busses/Auxes will show up in your Arrange Window. Do this for any and all effects, parallel busses, etc etc

2. ignore step 2

3. Turn on your Cycle range you want to export (yellow bar across the top like Marv said) and select all tracks you want to export

4. File --> Export --> All Tracks as Audio Files

5. If next dialog box doesn't have options showing, smash that Options Button and choose various options
  a. Range: Export Cycle Range Only
  b. Uncheck "Bypass Effects Plug-ins" if you want their processing
  b. Include Audio Tail and Include Volume/Pan Automation selected
  c. Normalize Off

6. I suggest making an AES-Standardly-named New Folder and exporting into that 

7. Export that bad boy

This will ensure you can import into your Industry Standard DAW exactly where they left off, minus the mix bus processing. 

If they're sharing effects (e.g. guitar and vocal both going to a verb), and you want them both wet but also separate, then they'll need bounce those separately or dup the verb send/return (in which case their Valhalla Vintage Verb will be 12dB too loud b/c they'll forget to turn off their 2bus processing when they bounce it separately)

author: Tristan
content:
Repetition, template, predictability = reliable outcomes. 

It’s as much about gain-staging as it is providing QC’d deliverables. Both inform how you work, and you might tweak your template to make your life easier at the end.

Be a minimalist in plugins, use less complicated routing schemes and mixing techniques - go back to basics and implement more creative approaches as needed. Most sessions of pro level mixers will be 80% the same plugin(s) because they know how they react. If something reacts weirdly, or a meter is going unusually berserk and doesn’t match what they expect to hear, it prompts them to interrogate and make changes if need be - I.e. rogue low end rumble smashing a compressor.

No one single person working at a high level I know works exactly the same, but they have some kind of process in place that works for their brain and business. Some more elegant than others.

author: Matt Huber
content:
What Josh said has been super helpful for me. 

Also, an easy thing to forget is level matching. Most tape plugins by default making things a bit louder, so make sure to compensate for that. Oftentimes, after level matching, I feel that a lot of tape plugins can make things come across “smaller” or duller  due to the transient rounding and (sometimes) the saturation. 

But also, sometimes those things are THE vibe for the song.

Then I leave the second slot blank in order to be able to EQ/de-ess/transient design/whatever before the verb—this way I can do most of what @bryan cook was outlining without extra tracks/routing. This all makes it easy to sync any predelay to the tempo of the song. I’ll often aim for something in the 60-120ms range as a starting point, whether that’s a 16th or a 32nd or whatever… OR I’ll just tweak by ear until it’s working. 🙂

author: Adam Thein
content:
This might be leaving the scope of normal mixing duties but a lot of times if I think the song calls for more consistent low end I'll perform/program a simple sub synth part with a preset I've made on Diva just so I know the sub is going to be always even and then blend it in where it's needed.  I'll sometimes double the same octave or do an octave below.  It's usually way down in the mix but for me it usually gets me where I want to be much faster than trying a plugin, although the only subsynth generator I have is the Brainworx one which is kind of hit or miss for me.  If anyone has a good rec for a subsynth plug I'd love to hear!

Edit: I think this comes in especially handy if you get a track with effects like chorus/phaser/flanger on a subby synth and your subs are shifting everywhere level wise from note to note

author: Slow Hand
content:
Like @Rollmottle said it's capable (I use it all of the time), but it lacks a lot of the really refined features of something like Pro Tools. But that's also because it's not trying to be the best mixing platform. It does a *lot* of things that make it preferable from a writing/arranging perspective, and that far outweighs the cons.

I wish it had EUCON support, because it's hard to get hi-res fader rides from controllers without it. Best I can do is do rides with MIDI values (only 128 values). My solution to this has been to map a MIDI fader to a *Utility* gain plugin and limit the range of the fader move to +/- 6dB so that I can get a good resolution with it across the range of volumes that I want to automate. But that's a pain in the ass.

That said, there's one feature of Ableton that I really miss when I use other DAW's and that's the *Audio Effect Rack* device. I use these *all* the time for so many things like parallel processing, or quickly disabling entire FX chains. They are incredibly useful and they remove the need to mult-out three extra channels to do parallel FX (like you would in Pro Tools).

author: peterlabberton
content: @Will Melones I’d check out the iZotope Tonal Balance Control meter. My room, with no corrective EQ, gets a little squirrelly below 150-ish, but with some EQ and that plug-in, I’m now able to dial in low end quickly and reliably. It’s pretty easy to see if something is really sticking out—has been clutch for both turning things around super quick on deadlines and also working late/quiet.

author: Slow Hand
content:
There is! It's called *RX Monitor.* It's a plugin that you can place in your signal path before you start editing.

You send your file to the RX standalone app for editing and it busses the audio playback from RX into your DAW so that you can monitor the file through all of the other processing you may have on your channel.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Ehhh. I remember in the late 90s or early 2000s seeing JJP on the cover of mix magazine holding a kitchen power mixer and i was just like FFS 🤦🏼‍♂️. They were definitely celeb mixers before the waves signature plugins come along. What i DO think happened is things such a s early Emagic Logic and their audiowerk8 card, and cakewalk and the echo io interfaces really started to democratize recording and engineering. Which fairly quickly led to plugins proliferating which then really led to those guys being more “household” names… or at least noticeable to people that didn’t own a purpose built studio and a couple of Studers. 

I think it’s the access to it all thats allowed people to get into it more, more than a Waves specific contribution.

author: GaspardMurph
content:
I’ve been doing the same thing with my PCM70, cycling through the patches. Sometimes I feel that what I like is that those patches are a little bit over the top but I never bother to edit them because it’s a PITA to do. Maybe with plugins we have too many opportunities to tweak em to “blend” in the mix when the opposite might be better.

Here are a few things I like to do with vocal FX:
- Chorus / Doubler that I then distort and will boost some high mid frequency (spectre is great for that)
- mono slap back is underrated, can be very appropriate in modern mixes
- Mentioned many times but compressing / distorting / EQing reverb returns (side chaining the compressor in the return with the dry vocal as key can really make vocal reverb bloom)
- Also, I don’t always tempo sync my delays, sometimes 300ms just works 
-

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
Sure- I think a few things. 

- The low likelihood of opening the session exactly (various plugins, like Joe said).
- I'm not doing any secret sauce most of the time, not much for esoteric techniques. Just really meticulous balancing, framing, polishing, largely *because* the larger moves have already been done. Not every producer is able to switch hats and approach their sounds the way I do (though of course some can). But my bigger concern is that I'm not sure they *should* take themselves out of the producer mindset, I think it can sometimes stifle the process.
- Not everyone I work with has monitoring that allows them to focus on the small moves the way I do.
- The amount of clip gain, volume automation, EQ automation, RX work, etc that I do......it'll take people a *lot* of time to do it if they're not used to doing it every day.

author: bryan cook
content:
My go to is a 16th note. It may sound like too much when the verb return is loud but when you sink the verb down it usually is really effective for me.

I like to use a mono aux with a delay plug-in for predelays, with a bus as the input and a bus to the verb as the output. No predelay on the verb itself, you make it before hand on this aux. Reason for this being you have a lot of control on your send signal that only the verb hears. A midrangey verb and a full range dry vocal make for depth and texture that can peacefully co exist. You can de ess the send harder than the real LV. With this pre delay aux you can make the send signal darker or brighter. If the song calls for it, make a second aux and have multiple predelays feeding the same verb. For example, a 16th with no feedback that is 80% wet, and a second input bus to same output bus that is dark 1/4 note 100% wet and with feedback where you can automate the send to that long feedback predelay and leave the short no feedback 1/16 static. You can get a lot of mileage out of the same verb with these multiple pre delays and provide some cohesive varied space.

author: Zack Hames
content:
You’ve got the right idea - The more different the left and right, the more wide it will feel. So you can change timing, pitch, and timbre/tone when double tracking to make it wide but also balanced. For example, double tracking guitars, keep the same guitar cab and guitar but different amp head. Or different pickups from the same entire rig. Etc. 

There have been a lot of good tips for layering vocals, to have the harmonies be different mics and preamps or simply stepping away from the mic to get more distance. 

As far as plugins and stereoizing, even a simple pitch shift plugin can do a lot. Delay 15-30ms each side, pitch +/- 5-10 cents, can get a cool effect if used subtly

author: aidanthillmann
content:
If you set up your Pro Tools template in a certain way, you can bounce stems super fast. I set up auxes and route stuff to them that will be a stem, so it’s part of the prep process (i.e. route Lead Vocal to Lead Vocal Aux, Keys 1 to Keys 1 Aux and so forth), so choose what you will for the song and split up however much you need to. Then I use sends (or you can multi-output) to respective audio tracks and name them (you can also include Instrumental, TV Mix and A Cappella as their own audio tracks). Record-enable all the audio tracks, record them down. Then use Soundflow to copy the mix buss plugins you need (Copy Track Data macro), copy them to all the audio tracks, then use Track Bounce to offline bounce all of the stems in one go, and it will include the plugins. Takes about 10-15min.

The only caveat with this is that you have to route any effects to the same aux, like Lead Vocal Verb has to go to Lead Vocal Aux and nowhere else, so you can’t share effects. But if you just create verbs for each thing as you go (or set up in your template) it’s no problem.

content:
1) Goodhertz is known for its UI. I find Faraday to be intuitive in a way other limiters aren't for me. The ability to alter the saturation is great. The warmth slider that makes a sound feel warmer or cooler is super fun to me. It's not transparent, but the limiting is gentler, so I like it guiding a sound into its place. Its goal is to make the overall artifacts of limiting more pleasing
2) I find it faster, more versatile, and better for limiting than a Vari-Mu emulation. Not to mention the UI is way more helpful than what I'm used to with a plugin looking to remind us of a Fairchild or similar
3) Yes, it just doesn't brickwall, and it has a vibe
4) You don't Need Tupe if you have a saturator you already like, but I adore it. I was skeptical at first, but I demoed it on drums, and it changed my life. Always on drums and bass guitar for me. Again, Goodhertz's UI makes it more versatile than any other Tube and/or Tape emulator I've seen. It has a million options to tailor the saturation. The Opto Compressor and simple EQ are fast and versatile. It sounds good

author: Tristan
content: While I now own well over 2000 plugins freezing is ideal in most circumstances because there just isn't a consensus on the way all plugin manufacturers authorize their products and that bites you in the ass. An example might be Goodhertz, which you may have installed once before as a trial or part of a bigger pack, but not authorized yet or the trial ran out. All DAWs will load the session with presumably no problems, but it's not until you manually open the insert itself that you realize the plugin has been operating in bypass the entire time. Waves even does a version of this now too, but it's active with 15-30sec intervals of silence. Multiply this with basically every plugin manufacturer and it becomes a very complex matrix. Furthermore, some plugins aren't as backwards compatible as they should be or different computer architectures impact settings carrying over. AutoTune (the bane of my existence) for a long time would flip settings if you went from a silicon Mac to an Intel Mac, but not vice-versa. Too many gremlins to account for to be fully reliant on their session as-is, but of course it happens. nature of the beast.

author: matthewrederburg
content:
@diamndsdancin 

This is good advice. Early on I spent a lot of time using exclusively plugins that modelled "magic" analog pieces. These plugins were supposed to add "vibe" and "mojo" and "that sound." 

Some of these plugins are indeed great, but the hyperbole use to describe them distracted me from learning about compression as a tool to solve a problem. These standard controls, like attack/release times, are the key to making the tool effective. 

Once you understand the mechanical stuff a bit, the esoteric "vibe machine" plugins become even more fun. Like, you're telling me your new favorite compressor looks like a soviet radio and only has one knob labelled "BLAST?" Well now your trained ear can hear that the BLAST knob shortens the attack time as you turn it and that's why it pulverizes the leading edge of your sounds. You knew you liked the sound of it before, and that gut feeling is valuable, but now you know you can use this fictional soviet radio compressor plugin anytime you identify a problem that can solved by fast attack compression. Brain meet gut.

You also know that if you're in a situation without your new favorite fictional soviet radio compressor plugin, you can likely achieve similar results using a different compressor. All is not lost and you live to work another day.

author: Slow Hand
content:
That’s the big hangup for me and many plugins that have skeumorphic interfaces made to look like the hardware: the controls are clunky and slow when used with a keyboard and mouse. They’re designed for hands and dont translate well to computer controls.

On the other hand, you have tools designed for computer like Pro-Q that are butter-smooth and intuitive with a mouse.

In the case of SSL EQ plugins, maybe the solution is to add an *x/y mode* where you can hold a key and then the freq knob controls both gain on the y-axis and freq on the x-axis.

author: Adam Thein
content:
If retracking is still an option maybe that's the ideal solution, but three things that come to mind to me to try if it's pretty extreme is pulling up the audio in RX and using the lasso tool to just track that sweep (it should be pretty visible and consistent if it's bad enough you are automating an EQ to duck the resonance) and just gain that down enough to be able to use other tools more effectively).  Another thing I'd try if you have it is soothe2 if you can get it to mostly work on that resonance without killing the tone (even maybe these both in combination) and then finally I'd try something like Saturn or Kclip in multiband and try and use a combination of dynamics and saturation within that band to tame it further.  If it's really bad maybe a combination of those 3, or just automating an EQ but that sounds grueling and time consuming if it's throughout the entire performance.  Maybe Surfer EQ could also accomplish this but I don't have that plug.  I also think there's a Surfer EQ type function in Nectar or Neutron?  Somebody that knows Izotope's stuff better than me can probably chime in.

My 2 cents and probably there are some better solutions out there but this is where I'd start personally!

author: mixedbywong_my
content:
Id assume it be a slightly slow attack in a context of a limiter instead of a compressor (longer attack time) 
You can if the limiter has a look ahead function built in. Taken from the fabfilter Pro L manual 
“Lookahead
The Lookahead knob sets the look-ahead time for the initial 'transient' stage. This allows the limiter to examine the incoming audio in advance and predict the amount of gain reduction needed to meet the requested output level. If the look-ahead time is very short, the limiter doesn't have much time to move to the desired level: this will generally have the effect of preserving transients better and increasing the apparent loudness, but at the expense of possible distortion. Longer look-ahead times are safer, but less loud, and transients might appear to get lost in the mix a little more.”

content: I use the TC clarity meter and am usually looking at an integrated level, in conjunction with the radar display which gives a visual representation of the track level. I don’t wait to measure the whole track, usually getting a handle of the overall integrated level across the loudest 30 seconds of the track gives a pretty accurate idea of how loud the track is. I’m also using the Klanghelm VU meter in RMS mode.  One other thing i’ve found really useful lately when mixing albums is using Izotope’s Tonal Balance plug to get a quick visual of the curve of the first few mixes after which I make preset based in those and use it as a quick ref when mixing the rest of the tracks. I’m finding a far more consistent result across a long project using this tool - especially when ears have gone a bit fuzzy

author: Slow Hand
content:
Well I'd say they were *designed* to do the same thing, but when it comes to actually coding the low-level DSP there are going be differences in how it's programmed/built.

Think of it like trying to null the Waves 1176 plugin and the Bomb Factory 1176 that comes with Pro Tools. They're aiming for the same target (emulate an analog 1176), but they were both built by different teams, and thus there will be variations that keep them from nulling, even if they're designed to do the same thing.

That said, I don't hear any appreciable difference between the two OTTs. For me it comes down to the Xfer Records plugin having  a more intuitive set of controls, so it's got my vote. 🙂

author: Deleted User
content:
1. Corrective EQ in the Upper midrange/high end, notching out all the harsh resonances, taming the pick transients if the bass is played with a pick. I love the way MAAT Santa Cruz does this ever so smoothly. 
2. I compress the bass with a compressor sidechained to a LPF(!), to get some low end body which is usually severely lacking. The LPF is set between 1000-2000 hz, attack 0-8 ms and release 200-400 ms depending on the tempo of the song/bass part. Reducing 3-5 dB on peaks. This gets me really far.
3. If the bass is a shortscale, I’ll use Goodhertz Tiltshift to move the low mids from around 200 hz to around 100 hz, out of the way of the guitars. 
4. Then I put an amp emulation on the channel. Whichever one floats your boat. Plugin Alliance B15, Guitar Rig, TSE BOD, whatever. I’ll be boosting low end and cutting high end here, or before with a separate instance of Tiltshift. 
5. If I want the bass to sound „rock“ and cut, I send it to a parallel distortion, which can be anything. I like TSE BOD, which is another sansamp copy which  has a lot of sub. My trick here is to add a clipper before the sansamp to really get extra gnarl. Logic‘s stock Bitcrusher works great, but I’m sure anything works.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
I have a full routing template including parallels, Inc ei get the files I'll organizettheninto their subgroups and everything gets routed. I just deleted the groups that don't end up with anything in them. I'm on S1 so it's easy to delete a lot of busses/channels in one go w a couple clicks. 

all my main sends are also setup but no actual plugins are loaded besides a clean gain plugin on my mixbus. I save my lost used chains/preset and I'll just drag them in as needed, I also delete the unused sends once I'm happy w the ones I got. as much as possible I duplicate the tracks and apply FX inline, makes exports so much easier. 

at this point I don't worry about getting my stem sound to be the same as the mix too much cause I try to get 90% if not more on the tracks themselves. my bus processing tends to be really really light. 

if a group works together I will do all edits I need to each element and just bounce the whole thing  as audio. I then disable and hide the old busses /channels, so I have a way to get back if ever needed.

out rn but I'll post a screenshot once I'm back on the desk.

author: GaspardMurph
content: Hey Chad, thanks for the video! I use the same technique as well. In my experience and after much testing, I have found that buffer size makes NO DIFFERENCE in h/w insert latency (at least with my Apollo interfaces, could be different with others but not sure why). Also, I had my HW latency dialed perfectly for each sample rate I use but since the second to last PT update (the one before integrated Melodyne), I have found that pro tools now calculates automatically and if I leave all HW latency at 0.0 in my playback engine, I get perfect null). Also! I have found that one thing that totally affects the number of delay is the settings of my interface, there are a bunch of settings within the Apollo’s (dsp load lock, UAD engine delay comp…) that will affect the latency. Hope this information might help!

Especially when someone is using their position in said industry to vaguely allude to some poor up-and-comers who are getting raked over the coals -- apparently -- by Waves changing their pricing structure. I was trying to push in to the facets of the industry that actually *are* predatory... the Social media folks, the engineers creating 'services', and yes... the private education system here in the US that preys on young professionals, gets them 100's of thousands of dollars in debt, and has no accountability for being accountable to any sort of result. author: Zack Hames
content:
What makes them think they *should*?  Steve Albini's Eletrical Audio videos are genuinely amazing and worthwhile technical guides to these types of things. If he's doing it maybe the person who's been mixing for two years should think twice about posting a video about compression ratios. It's not necessary.

And, there is a difference between someone out of the interest in their own heart and wanting to help, posting a "hey, some people ask this question and I think I have a helpful answer, here it is". Rather than "WELCOME TO "PRO AUDIO DUDE ACADEMY, TODAY WE ARE GONNA TALK ABOUT COMPRESSION" and then it's sponsored by some plugin company and they are telling you to smash that subscribe button.

author: cian riordan
content:
1. I assume you’re talking about multiple mics/tracks of the same source and checking the phase relationship between? If so, I never do this. I’ll usually re-balance the two tracks I’m hearing so they’re equal volume before trying to make a decision.
2. Surely. It works well for transient rich stuff like drums… less so for guitars/basses/keys… etc.
3. Some folks manually adjust the track and it can get dangerous if you’re mismanaging your clips…. I find using a plugin is a more fool-proof way of making these adjustments. I used to just use the stock time-adjuster in Pro Tools but lately I’ve been using the Eventide Precision Time Align because it allows you to move forward and backwards, as well as course vs. micro adjustments.

author: Deleted User
content:
Re: Waves’ marketing going off tangent from what Will said above

I don’t know if it’s waves’ contribution but there’s probably a lot more people wanting to get into audio engineering now. I think it is cool, especially in the age of “half the jobs are gonna be gone soon”- something like audio engineering can be a cool career path for young people to explore. 

About endorsements, just like how young athletes look up to sports stars - maybe some form of that is needed for young people to have some dream figures to look up to. Many people have said the marketing gloating illusive glamour and heroism in the audio world aren’t providing  a good guidance to people starting out, and I think it can be better for sure. I’ve been liking the panel talk MWTM has been doing in AES and NAMM, where they are discussing a lot of stuff that really matters. Stuff beyond turning knobs, discussing about what makes great records/record makers - I’ve learned a lot just showing up to those panels at AES and not doing anything else during the event. I feel like if bigger plugin companies do what Ableton does for their marketing (Loop, Livestream), I think it would be so much cooler and useful.

1) what sounds super grindy solo’d often sounds great in the mix. It’s one of those things that is counterintuitive but true.

3) if you’re a UAD user, their B15, dbx 160 & neve 2254 usually gets me a long way towards a tone I like.

My usual routine is printing different passes with different levels of reduction and then putting these processed takes in playlists synced to the original, this then allows me to comp between ‘reduction’ takes. I find it’s good to do this work separately to the actual mixing, or at least have a break before you mix as it can lead you down some dark alleys of bleed reduction. The passive listening Ruairi mentioned yesterday is key. It’s about controlling the bleed a bit better so that your vocal can be presented better.

author: Adam Thein
content:
Hey great question!  Even with “include return and master effects” checked in the export settings in Live, your tracks won’t 1:1 with dynamics processing or non linear processing (saturation) without using external side-chain routing.

I’d have a discussion with your mixer about if they’d like you to remove your mix bus or if they’d like it baked into each track/stem you are printing.  If it’s the latter, you can create sidechain source tracks to feed plugins that allow for an external sidechain input to keep it closer to 1:1 (still likely not fully accurate with the nonlinearities in some analog modeled plugins).

This is a pretty tough thing to type out but if we can find a few minutes today where our time overlaps I’m down to hop on a VC and show my workaround for this situation in Ableton.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
TLDR: Not sure, it breaks when I touch the controls so it’s not straightforward to check 😂

Long version: I got it a few years back and remember at the time cranking the input to see what it did, and it seemed like it did absolutely nothing. The manual says it has auto gain to compensate for altering the input level, but with whatever material I was using I didn’t hear any difference. To the point I actually assumed it was just glitching and the dial didn’t work. 

Moving to a better monitoring environment coincided with a pro tools update where touching any of the Ruby controls during playback causes errors and stops playback, so since then when I’ve used Ruby I just flip it on fairly early on in the process and mix into it with a high and low shelf and “preamp” on. If that isn’t the move, changing the settings is so laborious that I just use the UAD Pultec and dial that instead. Writing this now it sounds ridiculous 😂 But sometimes the gentle smiley curve with the kind of softening effect the “preamp” button has (it sounds like it just dips hi mids around 3k gently) makes things just sound like a record and I keep it on. 

Now I’m keen to check again and see if it does something I just couldn’t hear before. Let me know how you get on with it!

author: elvis
content:
So, I’m a long-time follower of this thread, but have been to scared to post any questions as I’m afraid to look like a total dumb ass…

I’m a singer/songwriter/guitarist who has been teaching myself how to record/mix over the past few years. I don’t totally suck, but I have a long way to go.

I’m working on a mix for a client—yes that’s new for me—and I want to kill myself 🙂

Basically, it’s a big, dumb rock song (I.e. Foo Fighters), and I can’t for the life of me reign in the drums—in other words, there’s freaking cymbal bleed in EVERY mic. So, I have this situation where I tame the shitty cymbals—then get something that sounds like kick and snare samples playing along to a vacuum cleaner. Mostly because I’ve put every stinking plug-in like Soothe, multi-band compression and dynamic EQ on the overheads and rooms. Yeah! My cymbals don’t poke your ears out—but, they also sound like a Rumba.

And gating did not work as the drummer is hitting his shitty cymbals on every freaking beat! I ended up sampling a god forgive—clean snare hit and using that as a sample. It’s okay, but without being able to raise the level of the rooms and overheads, I’m kind of fucked.

I found myself referencing this Joel Hamilton production/mix of a Highly Suspect song as it’s kind of similar to what I’m working on. It’s on Puremix. He’s pretty amazing. And while the music isn’t my thing—it sounds awesome. His mix sounds big and organic—while mine sounds like an electric ham sandwich.

Without hearing the song, I don’t know how much advice I can expect. I just mostly want to vent…

I sometimes wonder if I’m the one that sucks, or is it the source material? When do you know you’ve done the best you can with what you’ve been given? You can’t polish a turd. 

And as a newbie dipshit, I’m trying so hard to make whatever I do be super awesome, badass—whatever that means. But, maybe I just need to make the rough mix sound 20% better. I don’t know.

Wow! That was long. Thanks for any advice…

author: Will Melones

Share licenses how?

I used to print stems for a score composer who had 3 to 4 rigs for assistants. Plugin licenses were always a major pain in the ass. This is why I feel like I'm the only iLok fan on earth.

There were a lot of variables relating to MIDI programming and software versions and different humans driving, but I always found it much more accurate to stem from whatever computer printed the original mix.

Keeping true 1:1 clones was a dream of mine, but not practical for what we were doing

3. reso and all others

If you have soothe, you're good imo. 

I liked this one (speccraft) because it gave me more control when I needed to chase a more targeted frequency without affecting the rest (i.e vocals, bass gtr, etc), stuff like that, but I use these kind of tools sparingly. cymbals, egtrs cabs, things like that, almost never on the mixbus because IMHO (don't shoot me), soothe-like tools, affect too much of the signal - suppressing resonances/frequencies "killing the depth" because of the pushing down of reverbs, delays, etc. That is not to say I never use it, there are times for everything, and every tool has its place but yeah. There are people who use it that way and still get GREAT results.
As much as I want to simplify my workflow, 90% of the job is audio janitorial, I go back to simple eq, compression, fader...

I saw another comment asking about Spiff > I don't know if anybody wanted my input on that but nevertheless - I like it sometimes on drums after tape-sims where it kills too much of the transients if I need to drive it more for *reasons* but the sound is lovely (i.e country), bit of spiff after and get best of borth worlds.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
This might be a birdwalk...     cause I've developed the opinion that the difference between analog and plugin versions of the same circuit is the extreme abuse factor. Maybe I'm wrong again? Please confirm or deny based on your experiences....   But if the sound you liked came from abusing/blasting the analog version, you'll be unlikely to get the same flavor from a plugin.  G-Bus for example...  I have a rack unit and the UAD and NI plugin versions.  We can blast through the rack unit and get a lovely crunch that just doesn't happen in the software models. The plugins are as good or better at nominal operating ranges. But...  if you want to push the circuit, analog still does interesting things. 

I hope you find a plugin version and comment back...   does it More Better like the rack unit?

author: DarrenB
content: Another easy method for gainmatched reference is to use the Letimix Gainmatch plugin.  Load in your ref, mute the track.  Have your send Gainmatch on this and your receive on a listen bus (you'll want to make sure you avoid accidentally printing through it).  Gives a nice realtime feedback on where you're at level wise vs the ref (like Metric A/B), just another option I find handy if the sync or latch aspect of Metric A/B becomes cumbersome when you're not at the beginning of the timeline.

author: Josh Bowman
content:
For rock and folk music I generally just do subgroups like drums, bass, guitars, leads, bvs, lvs. For pop oriented songs generally more split out/ kick, snr, toms, hats, cymbals, fx, different synths split out etc. i just use soundflow scripts that solo and bounce what I tell it to and run it at night or at lunch. Freezing tracks first can make it go way faster. As for mixbuss, I take off my final limiter (or turn down the input, however the song was sent to mastering)… I’m usually not compressing the buss hard enough for it to matter. Sometimes the sum of the stems ends up sounding better than the mix! Generally people are using them for their MD to create a live show, or for dance remixes etc. For sync most people seem happy with instrumental and accapella in my experience so far?  Also if your trying to key your mix buss compressor from a printed mix, freezing most of the session first (besides fx etc and aux tracks) seems to help the side chain feel pretty close to what the mix was. I don’t bother with it though most of the time as I’m doing a couple db at most on the buss comp.

Edit: one other idea I’ve messed with pre soundflow, is, if your just doing subgroups and have the routing setup, save your mixbuss as a track preset and when your ready to print recall it on all your masters and commit the tracks. It works for me unless im using too much uad etc.

Usually for me I try to get the volume automation right for the music level first , then on the music bus , there is a fabfilter Pro-MB doing slightly bit of ducking triggered by the voice over track/bus. author: Slow Hand
content:
Got a question for my Audio DSP nerds: Does convolution of two audio signals introduce phase shift?

Convolution is most often used for reverbs, where phase shift is acceptable. But what if you convolved your audio signal with a fixed EQ curve that is 1 sample in duration?

As we all know, using a normal EQ imparts phase shift around those frequency bands, and an EQ curve with *lots* of bands, is likely to be a big, smeary, mess that distorts your phase relationships.

What if you took a big complicated EQ curve (like the type that you'd see on a Sonarworks correction curve), sampled that, and then used it with a convolver plugin to re-apply that same complex filter to your mix buss? Would this method sidestep the phase shift that you get from using traditional EQ bands?

author: JakeTB
content:
That’s all fine- it just needs to be transparent, rather than reframed in marketing hype. The “sale” nonsense is far from benign. It preys on beginners who don’t know any better and haven’t been in the game long enough to know their pattern. 

Fabfilter is a great example of a company with excellent history of support/compatibility and non-predatory marketing.

Make a good product, support it, and keep things transparent. Waves is 2-for-3 when they could very easily be batting a hundred.

author: JakeTB
content:
It seems to have too many angles for a short form conversation, and I’m struggling to articulate my thoughts because I have to filter some things. I really do believe that the way Waves has conducted business has taken advantage of some very vulnerable people, and has stifled a lot of growth. What’s worse, is they had the means to do this all better.

These views are based on daily interactions with these vulnerable people, not on having heard someone else’s opinion. They are also all said in cognitive dissonance as I use Waves plugins all over the place.

author: LAPhill
content: Isn't what Waves is doing just industry practice at this point, though? Unless you're Valhalla, basically every company does some variation of Summer Sale, Black Friday, Holiday, etc. etc., with varying deals throughout the year. So anyone paying attention to software purchases knows at this point that you shouldn't buy anything at full price unless you need it right away for something you're working on. If Waves is constantly on sale, then I'd suggest it's possible that it works AGAINST impulse buying by knowing you'll always have more chances (like Izotope). So the only people I could envision being truly swindled by seeing their sales would be people on their first day of ever buying plug-ins.

author: stefanmacc
content: If you have a lot of transients happening then try using subtle distortion on the close mics . That same lo fi plug-in can work somewhere between .1 and 2 db of gain.. that will even things out quite a bit. And then use a vca style comp on the overheads or something with a fast attack/release that can take any snare attack out of the OHs. Parallel comp on the drum bus can help too. I do multiple layers of parallel chains on my drum busses… vca compressors with a fast release are fun for this

author: Josh Bowman
content:
I just read through this whole thing, and keep trying to write a reply but it ends up being way tooo long.  Including this reply. Sorry for the novel.

I totally agree with you that the mixer should be able to recreate/beat the rough by rebuilding chains in a better way and not sticking to exactly what you did. . I do that routinely too especially on lead vocals, mix buss, and other important elements, drums etc. Whatever I hear could be rebuilt better, I will if I have the option/access to the unprocessed files and it needs it.

I guess I was more referring to when people take stuff off that is part of the vibe of the sound then say “do your thing, you can be creative!” and then when it isn’t identical to what they had, end up wanting me to use their thing because they heard it that way for 6 months.. ie really complex effect chains, a sound with 5 plugins stacked on it that, when removed totally changes the character of the sound, like @kylem  was saying which happens a lot with younger producers.

When you send serban sessions, even if he zero's out the EQs and redoes the dynamics, I think starting off where the producer ended still has an advantage for everyone to see how the sausage was made, then he can decide to re create the elements he wants to using a better recipe. John Hanes even wrote a post on GS about how they want the actual sessions that match the production, and if they dont get them, he will go bar by bar on an important project to match it by ear to the rough before doing the actual mix...

author: Jodonny
content: I'm not sure if this will be helpful to anyone else, but I feel pretttttty dumb after realizing that Dessers do not compress the frequencies you're setting in the plugin. Those are just the frequencies that the trigger the sidechain, like any other compressor. At least in Pro-DS and Desser. I've heard/seen multiple big mix engineers use these plugins to "just deess the high mids" (3-5k), and never really thought about it.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
specifically since I know you're in S1. if you have everything at a good balance I'd just select all the channels and bring the input gain down by 6 or however is needed to get you the headroom you want on the mix/master bus.  on the input mostly cause I'm assuming you have the waveforms at a good level of visibility at this point. 

I used to do the -18 thing but I stopped. felt like I was losing a lot of time and in most cases didn't make much of a difference. if it's not hitting where it needs to for some analog emu plugin I just gainstage within the the Plugins or, use the input or sometimes add a mixtool (utility) to make ABing easier. 

also in S1 you can bring down the inputs on all your busses before it hits they got to the master so you don't have to change each channel again and still get that headroom. 

as far as whether it's hogwash I don't think so. but i def coulent make it work. not for the type of music I was/am doing for the most part anyway.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
**The Lin/Log Thing with FFT**

So …. FFT and iFFT are a powerful thing. I’m gonna play fast and loose with technical accuracy here in an effort to make this understandable and actionable for a real record maker

At its simplest an FFT (Fast Fourier Transform) is a mathematical process that splits a signal into a bunch of slices/bands/bins (technically it’s component sine waves) which can be then acted upon or processed separately. This is *not* the same as a crossover or even a linear phase crossover, for various complicated reasons. The iFFT (Inverse Fast Fourier Transform) simply reverses this process and reconstitutes a single signal out of the many bands/slices/bins

Ok, off to a good start. It should be fairly obvious that the FFT bands in something like iZotope RX denote the number of bands a signal is split into

Now, the whole point of splitting is so that we can do interesting and useful things to the various parts of the audio spectrum. Something like Oeksound Soothe allows us to do very trick control of a signal in somewhat more powerful ways than a typical multiband. There can be downsides (time domain blurring - more later) but oftentimes they are worth the price of entry

Now, to the point of the post. The Linear/Logarithmic issue. Music/Audio is Logarithmic. What does that mean in practice? - let’s take A440, the next octave up is A880 but the next octave doubles that to 1760 Hz (not 1320 as might be expected in a linear system). There are lots of videos about the deeper differences in Lin and log, SPL is another log domain which is why we use dB (a 3dB increase is double the power in an audio signal)

author: Sam Segarra
content: Pulsar 1178 has a preset called "Over Compressed Acoustic Guitar" - that exemplifies a good starting point for acousticp compression. Essentially medium to high ratio, fast attack, medium to fast relesse and, importantly, cutting a good amount of low end in the sidechain so compression is only triggered by the transients. Any compressor plugin with a fast attack and a comprehensive sidechain should work.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Warmth

Alters the frequency-dependant characteristics of the limiter’s detector circuit.

A big part of Faraday Limiter’s thick, punchy sound is its frequency-dependent gain reduction. Low and high frequency sounds hit the limiter differently, and — depending on the Warmth setting — will exhibit different attack/release characteristics. High values, such as 100%, generally sound thicker and punchier, while low values, like -100%, have a quick, bright limiter sound.

For example, you can often use the warmth control to emphasize different aspects of a snare drum: more Warmth gives more thud & low end; less Warmth gives more stick & snare presence.

The Warmth control is not EQ, and will not change the frequency response of the plugin.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Definitely overcooked.
Don’t be afraid to kill all the plugins and start fresh with the knowledge now of what you don’t want to happen. The ozone exciter is often the culprit when I start to wince. 

Also, in a section like this where you’re going to really push up against the glass of the master bus, instead of pushing the brightness of the gtr have you considered temporarily dimming other elements? Sometimes I’ll put a c6 side chain on a few busses, and have it duck the them based on the feature element. Ie, often across the let’s bus or guitar bus I’ll have the vocals ducking specific harsh (or bloating) frequencies, just in certain sections of the song. Might be worth taking a look at.

author: Tristan
content:
Yah ofc

Biggest challenge for mixing - at least in my world - I get a lot of sessions that have crazy mix bus chains. Printing stems through mix busses, especially if they’re elaborate and working hard, rarely add up the same. Best strategy so far is generate stems with mix bus chain bypassed, then we recreate 1:1 in ProTools. There are a handful of plugins that are DAW specific, especially in Ableton and FL, so recreating those is near impossible, and I usually just end up mixing in the DAW or printing a few basic stems to keep the vibe and then pop back into PT.

My dream and current work in progress for this scenario is:
- Get stems (mix bus bypassed) and session from producer 
- import stems into ProTools
- ensure all stems feed a master 2ch 
- route that 2ch ProTools out via AUX I/O, loopback, omnibus etc
- new track in Ableton that picks up the corresponding input from PT
- delete entire session except for mix bus processing and send out my interface

This does work, and sounds exactly how I’d hope - but the latency is only just tolerable because it you’re on the higher side of buffer sizes usually to avoid glitches

Ideally I’d route it back into ProTools so I can print back in easily, but there are a lot more glitches and often increased latency, so I just print a clean 2ch WAV and import it into Ableton when I need to print.

Hella annoying and elaborate, but it’s the gig. 

The only other thought is looking into internal Symphony mixer and seeing if that can somehow improve things. That’s next on the list.

author: Tristan
content: Yah I have connector, it’s super handy. The challenge is the moment another plugin or app is involved the latency goes up by default. This is working good enough for now. Just annoying I need to bounce PT then into Ableton to produce a file. But I’m already nearly done with a Soundflow script that’ll bounce the pre mix bus audio in PT, import into Ableton, bounce it, reimport it back into ProTools just like it was a bounce dialog so probably stop here for now

IIRC, there was a bug with a version of UAD about a year ago where settings would reset to default under certain conditions. It's possible that this is an edge case where you two unfortunately happen to be on conflicting versions, or one of you has the particularly bugged version. 

If that's all it is, you can both likely update to the latest without losing any settings. (Obviously document/save a backup before doing so!)

author: hyanrarvey
content: In place of the original's wheezing 22MHz processor and 12-bit, 40kHz A-Ds, we now have a 450MHz 32-bit SHARC DSP and 24-bit, 48kHz delta-sigma converters, both from Analog Devices. The choice of a SHARC DSP chip makes perfect sense, of course; having put in all that effort into porting the algorithm codes to run on the UAD platform, it was almost inevitable that AMS Neve would use the same core software and technology to produce a stand-alone hardware version — and that's why my references to the UAD plug-in are so relevant to this review.”

author: bryan cook
content: I have always been from the school of make it sound as finished as possible as early as possible. It doesn’t have to be perfect but it should be close. You never know who is going to walk in the room mid production. Sonic sorting is important for the artist’s psychology but it’s crucial to inform the producer if it needs more or less and in what registers and counter rhythms. This sonic sorting may or may not involve plugins, could just be getting the source right if you have time. But sonic de-cluttering is not a wait for mix thing imho.

author: Deleted User
content: To me personally, throws are more about what effects are followed after. My favorite post delay/reverb effects Unfiltered Audio Byome. For workflow, this is 10/10. It’s a modular multi effect plugin, and making a few different presets on it allows me to quickly switch around between different colors and modulation. It has random parameter set feature and can unexpectedly bring in interesting sounds quickly too. Other than that, I also like Soundtoys stuff for phaser and tremolos, ubermod for chorusing and other phase effects on the delays. For reverb, Dverb is actually pretty cool especially when it’s mixed in with delays. I like Valhalla vintage verb and eventide ultraverb as well. And for post verb or delay saturation, decapitator and spectre. Saturn if I wanna use the dynamics control on it. I also like messing with the polarity, sometimes flipping it can get the presence of the tail heard better without obscuring the dry sound as much.

author: seb
content:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DWbFq2qiHGY

Let's talk clipping. Is there anyone here that works on modern r&b/trap records and uses clipping to achieve that FL Studio sound? Jon mentions it here, Jaycen mentions it elsewhere.

I actually come from producing on FL so I'm quite familiar with the clipper there and the sound that it gives off. I've used Ozone 9's limiter as a clipper on a drum buss while paralleling with soundtoys little radiator for that "FL" sound (as per Jaycen). It does sound nice, although I wouldn't say it quite matches the FL clipper. Jon mentions the tracks clipper -

author: Maxim
content:
I mean without music in context there's not a ton to say. And even if you managed to get the room out of the vocal (which with plugins like RX 8/9, C-VOX, SPL De-Verb, etc. is still not great) I doubt you'd be left with much that's "nice" to work with. 

But nevertheless, after doing some processing with the usual tools (best mentioned above - look into the new Dialog Isolate from RX 9) my intuition would be to eq the lower mids/lows first in the context of the music to get rid of the room "mud". 

Then maybe (lightly) slap some Soothe or Gullfoss on there to see what that does. Then once you've possibly got something to work with, go through the usual steps you might process a vocal with  (more additive/tone-shaping tools to get a sound).

Thing is, if you don't have all these plugins already it would be much cheaper to just record a better vocal. (I think you can demo them all though?) Maybe even consider renting a studio for a day (if the artist has the budget).

author: rse
content:
This is really valuable! Thanks a lot. To go into some of your questions; I'm using Adam a7's (not the newer a7x's, although I tested them and they're wasn't as much of a difference as I had expected in my room). My room has been treated with diy panels, 14cm thick Rockwool and it sounds decent for a home recording studio. the dimensions aren't great and low lend monitoring isn't top of the charts but it's workable. Any peaks and valleys i did have have been sorted out further as much as possible with sonarworks which has really outdone my expectations. I also use Beyerdynamics dt770 pro's. 
Usually a lot of time does actually go into clip gaining, cleaning up and taking harshness out of vocals. I often take as much time just manually leveling a vocal, taking out esses etc as I do mixing. Fresh air and dopamine have indeed been big helpers and have been big steps towards that sizzle. Also the waves exciter in parallel has been working okay.
I never seem to be able to get a multiband compressor to work well. Either I'm overdoing some of the setting or something because often i feel like it attenuates too much and other times to little in the places I want it to. I've noticed that a little boost in the low mids on pro-q3 that then also attenuates dynamically can work. 
Could you go into a bit more detail on what you mean with phase bringing a vocal more forward?
I've also noticed that a lot of the sound I'm looking for comes from a certain sort of rolling kind of sound that might be coming from the rappers throat? I'm not sure at all about this but it seems like it's almost vocal fry but in a very natural way that is inherent to the singers/rappers voice. Idk if this is a rapping technique thing or if this is more accentuated in the mixing process, but it sounds really nice.
Definitely a big thankyou for all the tips!

author: Maxim
content:
Verbs: UAD Capitol Chamber, UAD EMT 140, Seventh Heaven Sunset Chamber & London Plate and Valhalla Vintage Verb are frequently used. Verbsuite I have room and ambience presets I like sometimes. 

Delays: I like H-Delay to create the repetition and then add stuff on the backend to create some texture. Futzbox, Little Plate or Dverb, Little Alter Boy, etc. nice to get creative here especially with throws. Valhalla Delay is used mainly in production for me.

author: BillyC
content: Agreed with the last bit! But I actually don't think some beginners know what is meant and I do think it's important to distinguish between the terminology of 'secrets' and 'techniques'. I find that people like shitty YouTubers will often have you believe that that one single plugin or chain or technique used on one particular song that was discussed on one Pensado's place episode will transform all your mixes and get you to sound like mixer X,Y,Z. These ideas are missing an immense amount of context, making one specific use case of a technique sound like a deeply guarded mixing secret. I'm just trying to provide that context and I think that's what Matt and Jon are awesome at.

author: Iwan Morgan
content:
How are you all making stems for clients? My way recently was that every instrument goes to a routing folder (guitar 1, LVC, Bv1 etc) which them sums at another folder with my stereo bus processing on it. I can then commit all the folders but this doesn’t take into account the master bus processing which is a big part of the sound that people like. My old colleague David Wrench commits the tracks pre master bus and delivers a PT file with these commited files feeding his master bus (mostly waves plugins)
I’ve seen people use a sidechain from the master mix to print stems that run through the master bus but i’ve not had much luck with this. I would like a system that isn’t always a PITA to run once all the main mixes are approved.

author: Deleted User
content: I might be crazy, but every time I pulled up a simple HPF on a digital EQ(Ozone or FabFilter or the Logic stock one) I would hear this added bite or crunch, like a subtle harshness added. It’s a bit hard to describe. Anyways, it bothered me. So I started looking for alternatives. I found Crave, which in „analog“ mode didn’t have that crunch, but made the whole signal somehow softer/took away some clarity. Then I tried the MAAT, and when setting a filter I barely heard a difference, for the first time ever.

author: Deleted User
content: And then there’s the boosting: with FabFilter I find boosting mids/highs almost painful and the lows lack weight. I used the Kush Blyss for a while on vocals, but actually found the MAAT to sound both smoother and clearer when boosting mids/top end. Plus the lows have weight, I feel, and integrate into the sound well.

author: Deleted User
content: And for the blind test police: I only did blind tests with the MAAT and Logic stock EQ, which was absolutely night and day. I haven’t done one with Ozone/FabFilter yet, because I don’t have those on my current Mac. I probably eventually will, but the difference is so noticeable to me that I trust my ears. 🤷🏻‍♂️

author: Deleted User

author: ehutton21
content:
i just realized that i believe we’re talking about two different plugins! im using lift 3, I believe diamond transient is the one with the ability to clip in the mid range. i don’t have transient, but after my experience with using these across my mixes I’m pretty set on adding it to my arsenal. diamond lift 3 sounds big and powerful on bus and mastering duties. there’s a certain heft it adds in the clipping department that my other tools don’t have, but it’s compression and eq moves are actually quite versatile—it can be just as powerful but also surprisingly… musical?

i like compressor mode 3, clipped mode 1, and i gain stage the bus/track so i can drive the input on the plug-in, compress 1-2 db, drive the makeup gain of the compressor into the clipper so i’m on the verge of hitting the overs, then i gain match the plug-in to desired level. maybe add a little saturation there too. it’s got a subtle feel but it’s 👌🏼

my experience with this has been incredible with it on drum bus, music bus (albeit i’m not clipping), and mix bus especially when i get to the stem stage of my work in ableton (i do some stem work in ableton after doing the heavy lifting stuff in protools). pure insanity.

author: Zack Hames
content:
My day job is post production.  Usually post studios have WAY less mic preamps, microphones, etc. Smaller spaces. More seating, TV screens for clients to watch, ISDN / Source Connect patching capabilities for Voice Over Recording.  Way way less outboard.  Another big thing is Soundminer, an application used for SFX file implementation/organization. Very handy. 

a large TV screen, Soundminer, certain plugins (Nugen VisLim), 5.1 mixing capabilities, Source Connect connection, are probably the *biggest* things that a recording studio might not have. It's more that they're just way stripped down in comparison to music studios. 

As far as design, they're just usually really simple, clean, it's more meant for corporate clients and less for "vibing out" with musicians. It's a very different feeling world. I have no idea if this answers your question, but a recording studio should be able to do almost anything you'd need for post production, it's more about convenience when clients/creatives are in the room.

From my experience; 1. re-record 2. try to get it out with whatever you have, Rx, spl de-verb, waves ns1 and clarity vx, whatever tools you can think of. 3. Since it's REALLLLLY verby, just run with it. If it's impossible to rerecord or to polish it up with any tools you have, it's best to just go with that sound imo. It won't be amazing, but sometimes it just be like that. 4. Talk to the artist. Tell them straight up what's going on and give them the decision between rerecording and a mediocre vocal sound

Edit: use as little compression as possible, you don't want to be bringing out all that nasty verb even more

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
Ok can someone help me understand this?

Take any random audio, throw a gain plugin on it and increase the volume by 40db. It's going to distort like crazy. As i understand it, it's not your DAW clipping it, its the audio leaving the daw and clipping your convertors. 

My guess is this is Hard/Digital Clipping. But when I export the audio in the above scenario and compare it with the same thing but with a hard clipper plugin on the master, they do not null out.

author: rse
content: A hard clipper will behave differently than the digital clipping that occurs when you clip your converters or when you export a signal that exceeds 0db at a bit depth of 24bits. Your daw works internally at 32bits floating point, which means that your individual faders will have a lot of headroom above 0 db, so you can go pretty much as high as you want with them, as long as you turn the signal down in a later stage before it hits the final output. Otherwise you will be clipping your converters like you said. This clipping will be different for every converter, and it's why mastering guys buy converters that are worth more than your car, just so they can get a certain flavour when clipping their a/d (although I'm pretty sure most have stopped doing this, because it often just sounds like shit lmao). Clipping your signal with a plugin will introduce different distortion/saturation/artifacts. It will even be different between different plugins and between different algorithms inside of those plugins (if you are able to select those)  (some clipping plugins actually use the exact same algorithms, so those won't have any differences ofc. EDIT: the only differences here would be in the oversampling functionality etc. of the plugins used, not in the actual clipping algorithm. There actually aren't a lot of hard clipping algorithms out there, so most differences between plugins will be in the way the anti-aliasing filters work)

author: Jeremy Klein
content: Hahahah overall goal here is to match the sound of sessions I get sent that are distorting like crazy via signal going way above 0db, but with a plugin on the master so I have more control over the sound. Think chorus of Xanny by Billie Eilish.
