content:
Damn you just gave me an idea. I mixed a score once with different PT track folders for each stem, and dedicated reverb/delay returns for each instrument group to keep things separated.

I could offline commit all of the folders at once, and after a couple minutes of rendering I had stems. And in film it’s very important that the stems match *exactly*. BUT there was no master buss processing, intentionally.

But if you were to take your master chain and put it on, say, the last 5 inserts of each folder, identically, and only use dynamics plugins with sidechain inputs, you could feed your mix buss input to the sidechain of all those plugins. Then create a mix group wherein the settings for inserts f-j are linked…

This would obviously be an ITB-restricted solution with a heavy processor load. And I’m not sure how you’d set it up in Reaper, but it’d probably be even better than in Pro Tools

author: Zack Hames
content:
$7/month.
You have a plugin that you put on your master fader.
Setup a talkback (SM57 like you said)
Start up a session on LANDR sessions web page
It'll connect automatically to a webcam if you have one.
There's audio selections for your DAW or computer audio.
You can share your screen, and your web cam stays in the corner of your shared screen.
You send invite links and anyone can join via web.

It's stupid easy, genuinely.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
High passing the vocals right below the fundamental shouldn’t kill any low end thickness- if anything it’ll give you a little hump there. 

There are a lot of compressors that add low end resonance, some more musical than others. UAD 175-B and Fairchild do really well with that for my taste. 

Bottom without woof and top without sibilance are what make your vocals sound pro, and there’s no one way to skin that cat properly.

content: Settings change per source for me- but I generally reach for it when I’m looking for a real snappy electric or spitty vocal. author: Adam Thein
content:
If you have Fabfilter MB you can also get away with a lot of reshaping using a band in expander mode and then head into expert mode and put the sidechain in "Free," move to where the sound is most transient and use your attack and release times to really shape the sustain

this has helped me reclaim over compressed snare one shots with way too much high end sustain

author: Adam Thein
content:
I’ve always had issues with this feature ever since it launched with 5.0 - I’m still manually turning off sibilant detection everytime I load anything in Melodyne because if you do any sort of timing around sibilants there’s a small chance it becomes phasey with the crossfade of the sibilant in an unpredictable way.  I emailed Celemony the day 5.0 came out noting the issue and never had anything come out about what the diagnosis was for the issue and they haven’t ever followed up as far as I know (been reading the release notes since then to see if they’ve addressed it).  I really really wish they’d add a way to turn sibilant detection off for the melodic detection algorithm though!

Maybe it’s just me but it’s happened to me on both mac and PC in both stand-alone and plugin versions.

author: chadwahlbrink
content:
Are the vocals running through Melodyne or other tuning plugins?

You can get into some squirrely situations with tuning, especially if you place Melodyne in the chain later than insert 1.

I have experienced Melodyne slightly shifting timing over time. At least when using the plug-in version. It’s usually not a massive shift, but it could mess with the “pocket.”

author: chadwahlbrink
content: But using the melodyne plugin anywhere but insert 1 can really f you up… I got into trouble when I tried putting a natural phase fabfilter hpf before melodyne on a project once… the delay comp got screwy. Bad news.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I tried out the demo and was kind of put off by how severe the EQ sculpting is. It’s voiced very very bright. Maybe that’s the sauce in pop mixes, but it felt extreme to me. I found myself having to turn up the low shelf a lot to account for how bright it is.

The level rider seemed pretty good. And the compressor gets pumpy quick, but it was alright in small doses.

The doubler felt great and the two verb options sounded excellent, but I could see them being limited because they only have a dry/wet control.

Overall I like that it can act as an instant-vibe plugin for when you want to move quickly through a session. It’s got zero latency, which is great and seemed very light on CPU. But it’s not a fit for every style. Seemingly just for big pop stuff.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Many hands make light work! 
That tracks with my experience anyway. 

I usually find myself eq’ing multiple times in a chain- after each comp or saturator adds desired things, I often have a ProQ3 to de emphasize some of the unwanted things- adding in a couple db of dynamic dipping around the sibilance each time is really helpful! 

If at the end the esses are still an issue that’s when I break out audiosuite, but sounds like I need to dig into RX more. I loved it for killing mouth noise, but after I upgraded my OS & Protools Izotope plugs started crashing me, so I’ve moved away for long enough that it feels foreign again. 

As Jon Kaplan always says to me “work harder, dummy.”

author: Adam Thein
content:
If it's dynamics or non-linear stuff and you are bouncing the individual channels, the dynamics aren't really going to be the same anyway so maybe just bypass the dynamics or move them to the channels?  For non-dynamic stuff like EQ, I'd maybe just copy the plugin chain to each individual channel you need?  Otherwise yeah not sure if there's a shortcut in every daw for applying bus processing to individual channels unless you manually print each one.  If you happen to be in Live there's an option when you print selected channels to "Include Return and Master Effects" which I believe also includes any busses you are running.

Otherwise depending on what the stems are being used for can whoever you are sending them off to live with a grouped stem?  If it's going to an outside mixer maybe they'd be down to work from there?

author: ALXCPH
content: You could send a post fx send from the different stem groups to dedicated print tracks. That’s what I do, and it generally works fine. Then again I don’t have a 10 plug-in mixbuss that’s doing a million things.

author: Deleted User
content: Thank you for testing 🙏 It makes sense with reverbs. I’d have to test what that is like with saturation though (like tape delay or BBD), I like experimenting pre/post fx processing (comp/sat/eq) and polarity of the fx channel so it’s a workflow I can’t get out of quite easily. If all fx plugins came with L and R polarity switch that would be amazing.

author: ALXCPH
content: saturation does behave differently, like if you are saturating your bass and drums together. but you can fix that by sidechaining your saturation plugin to both tracks and butting the plugin on each track. that way you will get the stems reacting like they were processed together but still printed individually

author: Deleted User
content: That’s an interesting thought. I don’t remember ever seeing sidechaining option for saturation plugins I use, but I’ll look into this tomorrow. Thank you!

author: Zack Hames
content:
What @AlexL is on point and I’ve had a lot of the same thoughts as you but here’s my experience:

You can run your session at a very high buffer size which makes your session run smoothly while having low latency for tracking. You can use DSP plugins while tracking with this high buffer size and have low latency. 

That said, I was doing 24 track recording at 128 buffer size on a mac trash can (64 gig ram) with native plugins with no issue. Then i started working at the studio I’m at now and it’s an older mac pro and we have an apogee symphony with HDX, so I utilize that workflow there: using only dsp plugins and having the buffer size high. (While tracking).

Sucks about your car stereo man! had to live with only one side of my car working for almost a month once, it sucked 😅 

but yeah, agreed, Actively going in and listening to different frequencies to get to know them is such an eye opening experience(i still learn from it all the time) that i think everyone should do every know and then just to keep their ears and hz association sharp. 

Fabfilter pro Q has a feature that does exactly that vocal trick you talked about, Just make a Highpass filter, hold in the little headphones button while dragging the filter down til you stop getting useful information, and once you release it you will have everything above that left!

author: spectrummasters
content: Along with others suggestions , I would advise some easy quick  tools to help you diagnose  . Izotope insight has a very good spectrograph that clearly reveals what’s happening down at 20-30 hz and how much energy is there . We ve also discussed izotope tonal balance here as well , but it’s really a very handy diagnostic when used to investigate where your low end energy is against a referenced track you like . Izotope Match eq is another tool that again allows you to compare and contrast what’s happening in your low end . I’ve also found the Shawn Everett trick mentioned here , useful for investigating low end (put a brick wall low pass filter on your mixbus and sweep it down to the 20-30hz with your subs on and see what that actually sounds and feels like . The other thing I find helpful is my gain staging and buses are set up so that I know how much gr and level should be arriving at each bus , so you soon know if you’re too hot just by looking at the comp / limiter . The last thing I’d say is know your speakers . I apply all this to myself because translation is my main point of focus right now . I forget where I heard it said , but I heard it said that the listener hears the inverse of what we the mixers hear .

author: CK
content: just gonna throw this out there...Try the God Particle as your only mix bus plugin.  Use all the sweet spot targets, and forget about how much it is limiting.  Focus on getting the EQ targets dialed in with your mix, and the input target not clipping..  This taught me SO much about loudness.  My mixes consistently hit -9rms and -9 lufs when I get them dialed with EQ, and I no longer get the "smushed" feeling I used to get when trying to get loud. The mix actually breathes and is loud AF. Then when I get the eq targets dialed in, I see where I am hitting large amounts of peaks over 3-4db on the limiter, and then I address those peaks at the source in different ways. The God Particle I truly think can be a teaching tool, as well as a great sounding mix bus tool. I am now using it less and experimenting with my own chains. But seriously, this may help you as it helped me. The GP does not suck and I will always have it in the bag as sometimes it is just the right sauce.

author: stefanmacc
content: Nice okay , so to experiment with the idea of getting loudness or excitement without limiting … solo your drum bus and put the stock Lo-Fi on it. And turn up the bottom left “distortion” to 2-3 db and notice what it does to the peak level out of the plug-in vs coming in… you’ll notice it looks like it’s been limited. But it’s not. It’s just smashing the transients down and maintaining or gaining perceived loudness at the same time.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
I used to normalizw before starting but it was more about being able to see the waveforms properly for me. always ended up back at my same Initial  balances. 

some plugins like the PA channelsfor example  are supposed to work with similar gain structures as the analog counterpart but you can also adjust that in plug in settings so that it fits your needs. 

also know folk who adjust to make sure the master out is hitting their analog chain at an ideal level. 

nowadays if everything as a whole is way too hot or cold coming in I'll adjust clip gain or input gain for all tracks at once to keep the balance. doesn't happen too often these days.

author: David Fuller
content: This is bc most plugins (and most hardware clones) totally fuck the sidechain behavior

author: David Fuller
content: The original SSL and plugins that do it right have dual sidechains (one per channel) connected to a comparator; whichever voltage is larger is the one used to trigger the detector and make the vcas do gain reduction

author: spectrummasters
content:
....aw, found the old explanation of why....re: vu meter before the limiter and lufs after. 
This of course will be elementary stuff for everyone in here ...but might as well leave it here for a reminder/refresher. 

1. The VU meter to highlight how the mix is behaving pre-limiter :
VU (Volume Unit) Meters essentially display an average of what we hear, rather than the very fast peaks that we don’t. they will show you the energy in the low end, and if there is radical movement, then you probably have an issue with frequencies that you aren’t hearing.VU meters should “dance” smoothly and in a gentle manner, usually in time with the music, rather than in big jumps and erratic, out of time movement.  This erratic movement implies that there are drastic level changes, which will be hard to control in mastering and need addressing in the mix.  

2. The LUFS meter post limiter to set your loudness levels

Personally, i dont use this MO ...i like izotope tonal balance to monitor the mix but....just wanted to share what i rememmbered about people using vu ITB

author: GaspardMurph
content:
If anyone is interested, this is how I do stems:
1) once mix is approved I make a “master” session save as which removes all inactive plugins and inactive tracks
2) I make inactive all the tracks
3) make inactive all master bus plugins (I don’t think stems need to go through it)
4) only make active the tracks of the stem you want to do and offline bounce. I get a pretty big session done in 30/40m

author: Maxim
content:
And from the manual:
“The enhance process improves the perceived loudness and presence of the programme material by modifying the dynamic and harmonic content of the signal. Since the method used is different from the Pre-Processing section, it can further enhance the perceived volume of a previously processed signal, while suppressing all signal overloads. As the limiting action does not involve conventional sample value clipping, harsh distortions are avoided, and programme detail and dynamic information is largely retained.

Also, since the plug-in has internal headroom, transient levels greater than notional maximum modulation can pass from the Limiter section into the enhancement stage. This means that percussive overshoots, that would normally be lost in a conventional limiter (or would give rise to overloads), may be included within the sonic results of the plug-in, producing both richer dynamic sonic detail and a useful reduction in the perceived artefacts of the limiting process, all without giving rise to any sample value overload.

This property enables slower attack times to be used in the Pre-Process section, without creating output overloads, which would otherwise result in a need to reduce output levels.”

author: Joshua Riley
content:
What are y’all using to tighten up floppy kicks? 
I’ve been using Multipass as my go to for years but it’s on subscription and I’m weening myself off of all subs. Its pretty great at allowing me to balance the sub and punch content of kicks in a mix. It’s pretty basic, there’s two main knobs sub which is tied to the makeup gain on the comp on the sub frequencies. You have to dial in the threshold for it to work. Then punch just adjusts the transient shaper at the end of the chain.
I know that’s a pretty easy chain to replicate but just wanna see if there’s a quicker way of getting there, ie one plugin that does it all besides Multipass

author: f.ern___
content:
Here's what I did. 
Made session with a bunch of group channels. Namely these:
Kicks, Snares/Claps, High End Perc, All Drums, All Bass, All Music, LDV and BGV. 

Kicks, snares, percs was routed to the ALL Drums as well. Any transition FX was also routed to All Drums. 

On each of these groups I had an izotope insight 2 channel. 

I then loaded a bunch of stems and routed them to the proper channels. Some came with only a drum bus channel so I could check the kick and snare on their own. 

I set the levels so all mixes peaked at -4dB. 

Here's the songs I looked at:
100 Gecs - Stupid Horse
Ariana Grande - No Tears left to cry
The Weeknd - Blinding Lights
Charli XCX - Forever
Ava Max - Turn Off The Lights
Dua Lipa - New Rules
The 1975 - Give yourself a try

Here's what I found

author: BoozleBAM
content: Anybody here big on paralell distortion?? I really don't compress too much, and instead favor using a paralell channel distorted, which I blend in accordingly for whenever I want something to cut (standard technique). I have a few distortion plugins (temper, contrast distortion) that I rely on, but sometimes, when distorting in parallel, phase problems can occur. And I'm not a super phase freak, so if it bothers me, then yeah... The other day I came across a video of a guy using the "dr alien dirth box" https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLoBMNRsxCGeZXvtrNO7CGJso5yAmb2GcM on drums and I got to thinking it might be pretty cool to distort stuff through an actual hardware component rather than a plugin. Would going through an actual unit mitigate phase problems or would that not really matter? Anybody doing any cool parallel distortion stuff??

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'm a big fan of Goodhertz *Tupe* for parallel distortion. While it's not going to be the right flavor for every situation they implement it well. It has an excellent *Emphasis* section that allows you to emphasize/de-emphasize frequencies going into and coming out of the distortion circuit. 

This means that you can get the entire source sound to hit the distortion circuit evenly. Akin to making it fit your sound like a glove and saturate very evenly, rather than having the bass blow out the distortion before your mids or high-end can be saturated. Then I blend to taste with the dry/wet fader in the plugin.

author: Soundswithsammy
content: Hey All! My Mixbus chain has been a combination of the god particle limiter, and Ozone 11 and sometimes a Fabfilter L2 after, but usually just the God Particle to an Ozone. I've noticed lately, that when I go God Particle to Fabfilter L2, the sides of the music push out significantly more. I've been getting more clarity in the instrumentation of my mixes. The compromise is less saturation, but I think I like the separation (the fabfilter or Ozone limiter was only ever doing 1-2dB of work, but still completely changing that final spectrum. I'm having trouble telling how soon my mixes overload with the Pro L-2 unfortunately. Do you think wider is better? or is a trick and it's too wide, and all that width is overload? I have trouble detecting overload in my Insight2 Plugin, I only notice it on phone speakers after the fact. any advice to help decide?

author: Soundswithsammy
content: it's an ozone vs fabfilter question

author: Soundswithsammy
content: i feel like it hides in mixes that I finish with Fabfilter more than mixes in Ozone, but i get this width. I'm wondering if the width is even better to have

author: Iwan Morgan
content: This is a big topic and maybe the limiter is distoring because of things happening earlier in the mixing process (level and frequency balance management of transients etc) But if we keep it specific have you tried adjusting attack and release times and algorithms in Pro L2? Different limiter plugins react differently to mixes but it’s good to recognise the artifacts you are hearing

author: Soundswithsammy
content: It's really about whether I choose Ozone or Fabfilter, and the only other variable is GP. But I do appreciate the cieling info! I might try lowering my GP cieling from -.05 to -1, Just want to make sure I'm hitting the loudness I want for the track without peaking that's why i have that other limiter for safety. All great advice though!

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yeah. Less and less these days. A full mix might only have 2-3 effects sends on it. I've moved to a workflow where each channel (or group of instruments) get their own "send effects" right on the channel.

This is partly because a lot of the tools I use now include EQ and dynamics processing that allow me to sculpt within the plugin, and it's is partly because Ableton's rack tools enable me to easily set up parallel processing for effects within the channel without the need to mult-out or send the instrument to separate channels. It's way more efficient and easy to manage my sessions now.

I've been mixing consistently, almost every day, for 3 years or so and these are the things that I keep coming back to after having downloaded however many plugins. content:
Contrast Distortion mini: distortion
Leet Delay: clean delay for vox and anything that needs to be clean; room mics
Baby Comeback: dirtier delay for guitars mainly
Monsta Chorus: nice on bass
Mercurial chorus: bass
Modern Dyna Killer: 1176 emu
Modern Lost Angel: La2a emu
Modern De- Esser: "De -esser"
W-1 Limiter: Limiter
Room Machine: weird reverb stuff on sends
Room 041 Analog Obsession: Very nice room emu/ reverb
Ro Gold: Plate Reverb
V Rev 666: very nice spring reverb
Dead Duck gate: Beautiful colored gate
Reapitch: For minor "cents" changes in pitch if I absolutely need it
ReaEQ: Parametric EQ
Smack Labs Logic Channel: SSL emu. I only use it for the high shelf 
Ampeg SVT: Not a paid plugin, but I got it for free on their hand-out day
False FL: A beautiful stereoizer plugin. The only stereo plugin I've ever liked. Guitars
PTeq-1A: My fav Pulteq emu


Honorable Mentions:

Temper: distortion
Apocrita: Distortion
JB Red Phat: Crazy nice sounding compressor thing. Complex.
Epic Verb Vos: Multi reverb unit
Echo Thief Repository: A bunch of different IR reverbs
Grant Nelson Lexicon Irs
G Gate: Very nice, transparent gate
TSE Bod: Sometimes it's alright

author: JustinLeu
content:
Clippers can be great on busses. Great on drums etc… I find Standard Clip to be super intuitive to use and you can visualize what is happening. (Probably helpful if you are trying to gain understanding)

On the mixbus it can be helpful before the limiter but most of the time I would introduce it towards the end of a mix if at all. I would try hard clipping or a more gentle knee and see if between that and a limiter I can get something better than limiting alone.

Keep in mind that any saturation plugin (tube/tape) on the mix bus is “clipping” (soft clipping) and I find that gain staging in to that type of processing is more friendly to mix in to rather than hard clipping.

author: river
content:
Ableton chain 
Two chains, one called, left one called right. Pan each to the respective channel.
Left channel, invert phase, distortion plugin, invert phase again,
Right channel have the same distortion settings (or similar) 
It will create some difference between the two channels due to how the distortion plugin reacts (non linear process)

author: yaldaram
content: TLDR: The document discusses the claims of sound quality and superiority between different audio software. It concludes that no evidence supports these claims, and any perceived differences in sound are due to variations in software algorithms, particularly in how they handle signal levels and pan groups. These differences do not indicate one software's superiority over another but rather reflect different mixes with varying balances. The document also highlights that any discrepancies caused by third-party plugin incompatibilities should not be mistaken for differences in sound quality. The concept of "better sound" is subjective and not quantifiable.

author: EliHeathMusic
content:
I’ve been thinking a lot about how I deal with resonance and unwanted harshness recently and would love to hear about how you all approach this (and maybe more broadly how you think about restraint and taste when using modern plugins). We have so many powerful tools at this point for cleaning up audio (eq, rx, soothe, spectral shaper, de-essing, etc) but when I listen closely to a lot of my favorite recordings from the last 70 years I’ll hear all sorts of weird resonances and abnormalities. 

Over time I’ve been getting better at finding a balance of how far to go with these tools and have also become aware of how easy it can be to go overboard sometimes. Beyond reps and intuition, are there things that have helped you hone in on this? And are you consciously adjusting your “threshold” based on the music or genre you’re working with or do you have a general taste for how you like to hear things regardless of the style and use other tools to get the character and vibe you’re going for.

In other words, do you think about how far you go with these tools as a creative and stylistic decision or more of a functional one?

author: Slow Hand
content:
Actually, delays are super easy. You just input a quick blast of white noise (your impulse) through the delay device and record the output. That output becomes your IR which you can then use in any convolver plugin to apply echo to your sounds.

Of course it's not that useful because you can't tweak the echo parameters. You'd have to capture an IR for every setting that you want.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
A year or so ago I went deep on this. 

First thing is, and you’ll hear this a lot around here, monitoring. Making sure your monitoring is good will allow you to hear where the esses are problematic and when you’ve gone too far, etc. 

Secondly, all my de-essing woes pretty much disappeared when I started using RX. 90% of the time I run DeEss module and slap Waves DeEss (around 7khz) on the end of the chain and it’s golden. May still have to clip fx / clip gain one here or there but it’s largely just handled.

The artist allows me to mix the instrumental i produce, and i am aware that i need to take the limiter off when sending these files out for mastering.  

To be honest, i'm not understanding the external sidechain part you're talking about. Maybe i'm not experienced enough 😦 I mostly use sidechain for bass/808 and instruments and the input would be the kick. I haven't try sidechain for other any purpose than that ever. And the SPL IRON i'm talking about is a plugin. Could you please elaborate more about "feed plugins for externsl sidechain to keep it closer to 1:1"? Thanks Adam!

author: Adam Thein
content:
All good it’s a little tricky at first and just really difficult to explain typed out for me.

Same concept as using a sidechain input from a kick drum to duck the 808 - an external sidechain allows us to give the compressor something to listen to and apply the compression from that source to another source.  When the kick is fed to a compressor on your 808 channel - the compressor “listens” to the kick and applies the compression curve from the kick onto the bass.

So in your case of printing stems with a mix bus compressor - you want the SPL Iron plugin to “listen” to the entire mix as it heard it before but then apply that compression to one track at a time.

We can do this in Ableton with some clever workarounds, which would be a lot more efficient to show you on a video call on the server if you are free later.  Essentially you need to print a version of your song at each point in your mix bus chain where there are dynamics plugins (just before the Slate plugin, just before the Iron Compressor but after all the other plugins) and then send that audio to those corresponding plugins’ external sidechain inputs and then you can use the “include return and master effects” and get the result you are looking for

author: earwormfarmer
content:
I’ve also been loving the unfairchild plugin and it’s great on the mixbus imo. Recently have been using it for back-bus compression, a technique I heard Andrew Scheps talk about which is basically a copy of the mixbus minus drums. Mix bus stays uncompressed or less compressed. Back bus gets compressed more aggressively than I would do a mix bus. Blend that under the mix bus to taste. Really good for locking all the instrumentation together around vocals without dynamics getting pulled around by the drums. I think Andrew uses some kind of 1176 but the idea works with all kinds of compressors.

Mix bus and backbus both feed into a 2-bus where more processing may happen. Something like Pultec EQP1q, tape emultion, Pro L2? But I like to change things up!

author: Jack
content:
Going to assume you’re talking more Rumours than Aerosmith.

Drums: dbx 160, transient designer on close mics to thud things up, Fabfilter Saturns ‘dynamics’ knob works quite well to tighten things too, no slammin’ compression on room mics/overheads, sometimes hi-passing overheads into being ‘cymbal mics’ and giving the close mics their space 

Vocals: Dolby trick, not always super aggressively hi-passed, H3000/Microshift backing vocals

Guitars: acoustic 12 string layers, phasers/flangers, mid-forward drives, acoustic guitars often super hi-passed 

Bass: flatwound strings, picked 

Annoying answer: it’s mostly in the arrangement

content:
This goes back to “what helps you get the job done quicker?” 

You can 💯 make something ace with stock Ableton plugs. But if a plug-in for 29.99 helps you ace one gig it’s paid for itself hundreds if not thousands of times over. 

I don’t want anyone to go into crushing debt for new toys. And financial stress can really negatively affect some people’s work. Other people it lights a fire under. Personally, if I want to de-ess, which is something I do many many times over in every song I’ve worked on, $30 seems like a steal to just have something that one click works. author: Sei046
content:
I would definitely say the chain, say fx, pre, mic etc is almost inconsequential against the vocal performance. Every extra minute spent on trying to iron it all out there will save you hours in editing and mixing. I’ve often considered selling a piece of gear and then had a really stellar vocal go through only to realise there was nothing wrong with the gear. I’m sure you’re sick of reading it but the performance is everything. You can’t REALLY EQ air and body into a vocal that isn’t there. You can’t try simulate it alright. And you can’t create actual excitement with compression, just try and trick the brain into thinking there’s excitement. A 57 into any preamp into any interface with a stellar performance will sound amazing. 

After that is just treatment, and it’s essentially pointless discussing chains because it’s so song and vision dependant. 

A boring answer I know but you’ll save a lot of headache and heart ache the sooner you learn it. 

It’s like when you hear a new compressor plugin just explode a drum room and it sounds amazing. Analogue glue, explosive release, so much groove. And then you slap it on the lacklustre room and performance you actually have in front of you and it doesn’t seem to sound so amazing any more.

author: James Cronier
content: I've had the opportunity to scrutinize and explore the fundamentals in my recording work recently. that's why my first suggestion for someone curious about vocal chains find a way to observe a recording session. so one can see everything that goes on that isnt gear or plugins or setup. 'cause everything is a piece of the oh-so-mysterious whole. and yet it stops being mysterious once we are on the other side of all the speculation.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Conceivably any vocoder would be sufficient because the harmonic richness depends on the carrier signal you feed into it, which could easily be any bright synth that you have on hand.

That said, even if you have a darker carrier signal you can usually “tilt” the vocoder bands towards more high end energy and less low end if you want it brighter.

Have you tried Izotope’s *Vocal Synth 2*? It has lots of vocoder-adjacent effects that will do similar things.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Oh interesting - For some reason my journey has led to me only reaching for the CLA76 on a parallel for the bass, but I should try it again in other contexts.

In case anyone would wanna try my approach to getting bass to play nice across more speakers / phones:

- I use the 20 ratio bluey to squash a bass parallel. Then I drive it through the free TSC 808 plugin for further emphasize the harmonics the bluey brings out. (EQ too)
- Then, I use Audreio on the master to play the mix through my phone instead of my monitors. Once on the phone, you can blend the parallel with the bass in a way where there’s little to no audible difference on a monitor, but the illusion of a bass can be heard through the harmonics playing on the phone.
- It’s a balancing act, but there’s almost always a nice sweet spot to be found where it doesn’t change the quality of the sound enough to be intrusively perceived on HD speakers, while giving life to the bass on lesser speakers.

This has helped my bass translate to more systems, and is the only time I find myself wanting to use the CLA76.

author: Ed Sokolowski
content:
SNR thing is somewhat overblown IMO, especially these days. Background noise is going to be quite a lot louder than A/D noise unless you have a really old interface, or really quiet signal. Even in ideal conditions, DI’s are unlikely to have more than 100dB in dynamic range.

There’s also a thing where a lot of amp sims need REALLY high (like un-intuitively loud) signals. To reach “unity” gain in Softube’s Marshalls or a lot of Amplitube amps, you essentially need to be just below clipping and then boost another 10-15dB or so

Also have done quite a few live recordings (mostly ccm) depending on how it is edited/tracked, the drum bleed in to the vocals will be something to figure out. 
A few things I have had a lot of success with:

author: JustinLeu
content:
I agree with @Jonathan Jetter  that the simplest solutions really work 99% of the time. 

My guess is it is simply a level issue. Don’t be afraid to crank away on the waves deesser….you will know when you’ve gone too far, and sometimes will be surprised how much you need to do for it to sound “natural”.

They also may be annoyed with the “flamming” of the esses or consonants, depending on how the vocals are being mixed (duets style vs lead/bgv) 

Which ever vocal is the lead needs to win, if it is split lead I would advise organizing the tracks accordingly and then attenuate the non-lead track esses more…and line them up as needed. 

I am doing exactly the same as @Jonathan Jetter  and pretty much in that order.

Also food for thought, most of these fancy tools did not exist 10 years ago and engineers have made esses sound great/believable since sound recording began. 

I used to obsess over them too and I eventually realized it is almost always a level thing not some mystery treatment. 

Last thought would be on “replacing” esses. That tends to be most useful when the phrase timing does not work, ie. too short for the timing of the phrase. Usually leaving the tonality of the esses makes a performance feel more real and human.

author: Alex Gamble
content:
Soothe is an interesting one. Much like how every plugin manufacturer has their version of classic pieces (1176, LA-2A, 1073, etc), now we're starting to see every plugin manufacturer have their version of someone else's plugin! I can't think of any other examples off the top of my head.

I agree with the previous posts, a resonance supressor is useful and a must-have in the toolkit, but extremely easy to overuse. Don't get too caught up in the marketing hype that these will solve all your mix problems. That said, sometimes it's just what the doctor ordered.

author: Alex Gamble

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Update on my UAD woes (since everyone's been on the edge of their seats). It took a Saturday afternoon and a lot of waiting for things to load, and I'm not sure which step actually fixed it but here's everything I did, just in case it helps someone:

- Updated from Mac OS Monterey 12.4 to the final iteration 12.7.6 
- Uninstalled all UAD software using their uninstall process as prescribed on the UAD site
- Reinstalled UA Connect (latest) and reinstalled everything. 

My missing plugs were still fucked at this point so...

- Deleted UA connect and downloaded a legacy version with confirmed compatibility with OS 12.7.6. It immediately auto updated itself anyway.
- Used the Uninstall buttons per plugin within UA connect, then reinstalled

Still no joy

- Closed Cloud Session in iLok License Manager
- Reopened Cloud Session

Nothin'

- Deleted iLok License Manager and all attendent prefs etc
- Installed latest  ilLok License Manager

Still nothin' 

- Manually deleted all of the .aax UA plugins in my PT plugins folder
- Hit the uninstall button per plugin in UA Connect to reveal the Install button again
- Installed all plugins again

Finally got the bastards working!

author: James Cronier
content:
I’ve been using the SSL native E-channel as a go to mixing insert on most every channel for the whole year. I turn off the VCA distortion by default (the extra THD is not welcome here). 

As a mixer, I find the stereo pan really useful in pro tools, the input/output gains handy, and the EQ and dynamics to be really versatile and consistent. I don’t have to think about building a chain, 90% of the time all the tools I need are there. Also, the EQ maps perfectly to the avid artist mix  encoders so I don’t need to look at the screen to EQ.

I’m a little skeptical that these other plug-ins would sound so much better as to really change things for me, but this discussion does have me thinking.

author: cian riordan
content: Do some research on LUFS and start using a LUFS meter at the very end of your mix bus. Many plugins (like Ozone & Pro-L2) will have it built in already.

author: cian riordan
content: But if you're leaning into an analog emulation, then 0dBVU within that particular plugin is a good place to start.

author: cian riordan
content: If you're going into a Tape emulation or a saturation plugin, then you probably want to go a lot lower than 0dBFS unless you really want to distort your mix.

author: Juliette
content: I would’ve never even thought of that! I usually will leave the plugins alone (depending on what kind is being utilized) and mess with the clip gain. I’m still trying to feel out what’s my preferred method of volume adjustment between plugins, faders, and clip gain

author: thegreatcarsoni
content: The best mixes i've done (in terms of how they feel and how quickly they get approved) have been since I started with a pretty heavy hand on the mix bus. it keeps me from overprocessing and loading up the session with plugins unnecessarily, and also makes it easier to sort out what parts of the mix are most important. My brain has never liked starting with limiting on for anything but the most aggressive stuff I've done, but I'll probably change my tune on that at some point.

author: Slow Hand
content: I just hope they get wise and tone down this *very* permissive demo version. Which only makes the plugin go silent for 1.5 seconds every 25 minutes. 😄

author: James Cronier
content:
FWIW I like the GUI, I find it really easy to understand, the emphasis curve vs. threshold being the meat and potatoes of the whole thing. I think they did that well and focused on the right thing which is the horizontal scaling in the frequency domain. Soothe gets this *quite* wrong imo. As far as looks, whatever, it’s kinda a Fabfilter rip, ig. 

Knob feel isn’t great, maybe they can fix that. Holding the fine tune modifier helps.

author: Matt Huber
content: Exactly my experience. And much agreed on the GUI - it’s a bit rough. It’s so interesting how much the UI/UX impacts adoption. In its current state it is an insanely useful tool, but yeah it’ll never sell as well as the pretty plugins 🙂
